article.title: The SCons Gnuplot tool

section.title: Basics
section.para: This tool tries to make working with Gnuplot in SCons a little easier. It provides a generic builder named GplotGraph to generate graphs with gnuplot. The typical use of gnuplot is to generate one or more output files (with graphs) according to a recipe prescribed in user-provided gnuplot script(s). To generate the graphs, the script often reads data from input files (e.g. numerical data from *.csv files). The graphs are written to one or more outputs.

Through this manual we'll use the following terminology:
Script (file) Source (file)
or gnuplot script. A file containing gnuplot commands to be processed by gnuplot. The (list of) gnuplot script(s) (file names or nodes) is provided by the user as the source positional argument to a builder.
Input (file)
additional input, script input. Used to denote any additional file needed by the script (read access). For example, the script may read data series from *.csv file as a part of plot command. The input files are not mentioned in source parameter to a builder, but may alternatively be listed via gp_inputs keyword parameter. A single script may use more than one inputs.
Output (file)
or script output. Used to denote any file defined in the script with set output command. Note, that a single script may generate more than one outputs. Files produced by gnuplot script, but not explicitly listed by set output command, are called extra outputs and may be listed in gp_extoutputs keyword parameter.
Extra output (file)
a file produced by gnuplot script that is not explicitly defined by set output command. Extra outputs may be listed in the gp_extoutputs keyword parameter. Extra outputs are generated implicitly by some gnuplot terminals, for example epslatex generates *.tex file as normal output and *.eps as extra output.

Although the gnuplot script contains information about its input and output files, it is not trivial to extract this information. The gnuplot scripts are not so easily parsable from python, and gnuplot does not provide any facilities to extract dependencies (correct me please, if I'm wrong). Instead of writing cumbersome scanners and emitters, we chose different approach described below.

The list of all input files to gnuplot script has to be specified explicitly in SConscript (outputs may be given in SConscript too). Currently the only information extracted from gnuplot scripts is a list of output files defined with set output command. This works only for file names given by value (that is the file name is extracted correctly from set output "foo.png"; but from foo = "foo.png"; set output foo; will not be extracted at all). There are also other limitations, such as that the set output has to be the only command in its line or that the file name must not contain quotes (for example, set output 'str"ange".name'; will not be processed correctly). More elaborate scanners/emitters may appear in the future. To avoid duplication and achieve some level of consistency between SConscripts and gnuplot scripts, the names of the inputs and outputs defined in SConscript may be passed to gnuplot via command line and made available to the gnuplot script in form of predefined variables.

section.title: Specifying input files explicitly
section.para: The input files (but not sources) are specified via gp_inputs keyword parameter. The gp_inputs are added as implicit dependencies to each source listed in source positional parameter.

section.title: Specifying output files explicitly
section.para: The output files may be defined via target positional argument and/or via gp_outputs keyword parameter. You may mix both methods. The file names listed in gp_outputs are passed to gnuplot command through the command line (as gnuplot variables). The script may then use these variables instead of hard-coded file names.

section.title: Specifying extra output files explicitly
section.para: The extra output files may be defined via target positional argument and/or via gp_extoutputs keyword parameter. You may mix both methods. The file names listed in gp_extoutputs are passed to gnuplot command through the command-line (as gnuplot variables). The script may then use these variables instead of hard-coded file names.

section.section:
Choosing names for the command line variables You may decide what the names of the gnuplot variables should be. Just use dictionaries instead of lists for gp_inputs , gp_outputs , and gp_extoutputs , for example
GplotGraph('foo.gp', gp_outputs = { 'varname' : 'foo.png' } )
where 'varname' is the name of the variable carrying out the 'foo.png' file name to gnuplot.

section.title: How gnuplot is run
section.para: By default, gnuplot is started from the directory containing SConsctruct/SConscript file invoking the GplotGraph builder. Variant directories are respected, and in VariantDir build the gnuplot is invoked from the build dir.

The default behavior may be changed by altering the chdir parameter of GplotGraph builder. If you need to start gnuplot from another directory, pass it via the chdir.
GplotGraph('foo.png', 'foo.gp', chdir = 'bar/')
If you pass string as chdir it is interpreted as directory name relative to the place where SConsctruc/SConscript lives (unless the name starts with #).
You may also set chdir explicitly to None or False to revert to default SCons behavior (running from top-level source directory).

article.section:
Examples
This section contains several examples, starting from simplest ones and ending with most advanced ones.
Single output, everything hard-coded in *.gp script
Single output, everything hard-coded in *.gp script
In this example we generate a file named singleout1.png containing the graph of sin(x) function.
singleout1.gp script:
# singleout1.gp set terminal png; set output "singleout1.png"; plot sin(x);
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph('singleout1')
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot singleout1.gp os.chdir('#')
Single output, pass output file name via command-line
Single output, pass output file name via command-line
In this example we generate a file named singleout2.png containing the graph of sin(x) function. The name of the output file is defined in SConsctruct (the gp_outputs parameter) and passed to gnuplot via command line as a gnuplot variable named output1.
singleout2.gp script:
# singleout2.gp set terminal png; set output output1; plot sin(x);
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph('singleout2', gp_outputs = [ 'singleout2.png' ])
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'output1="singleout2.png"' singleout2.gp os.chdir('#')
Single input and output, everything hard-coded in *.gp script
Single input and output, everything hard-coded in *.gp script
In this example we generate a file named singleinout1.png containing a graph of numerical data from singleinout1.csv file. The names of the input and output files are hard-coded in singleinout1.gp script.
singleinout1.gp script:
# singleinout1.gp set terminal png; set output "singleinout1.png"; plot "singleinout1.csv" with lines;
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph('singleinout1', gp_inputs = ['singleinout1.csv'])
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'input1="singleinout1.csv"' singleinout1.gp os.chdir('#')
Single input and output, pass file names via command-line
Single input and output, pass file names via command-line
In this example we generate a file named singleinout2.png containing a graph of numerical data from singleinout2.csv file. The input and output files are defined in SConsctruct (the gp_inputs and gp_outputs parameters) and are passed to gnuplot via command line as a gnuplot variables named input1 and output1 respectively.
singleinout2.gp script:
# singleinout2.gp set terminal png; set output output1 plot input1 with lines;
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph('singleinout2', gp_outputs= ['singleinout2.png'], gp_inputs = ['singleinout2.csv'] )
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'output1="singleinout2.png"' \ -e 'input1="singleinout2.csv"' singleinout2.gp os.chdir('#')
Single output and two input files, pass file names via command line
Single output and two input files, pass file names via command line
In this example we generate a file named doublein1.png containing a graph of numerical data from separate files doublein1_1.csv and doublein1_2.csv. The names of the input and output files are passed to doublein1.gp script via command line.
doublein1.gp script:
# doublein1.gp set terminal png; set output output1 plot input1 with lines, input2 with points;
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph('doublein1', gp_outputs= ['doublein1.png'], gp_inputs = ['doublein1_1.csv', 'doublein1_2.csv'] )
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'input2="doublein1_2.csv"' \ -e 'output1="doublein1.png"' \ -e 'input1="doublein1_1.csv"' doublein1.gp os.chdir('#')
Two input and two output files, pass file names via command line
Two input and two output files, pass file names via command line
In this example we generate two files named doubleinout1_1.png and doubleinout1_2.png containing graphs of data series from files doubleinout1_1.csv and doubleinout1_2.csv respectively. The names of the input and output files are passed to doubleinout1.gp script via command line.
doubleinout1.gp script:
# doubleinout1.gp set terminal png; set output output1; plot input1 with lines; set output output2; plot input2 with lines;
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph('doubleinout1', gp_outputs= ['doubleinout1_1.png', 'doubleinout1_2.png'], gp_inputs = ['doubleinout1_1.csv', 'doubleinout1_2.csv'] )
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'output2="doubleinout1_2.png"' \ -e 'input2="doubleinout1_2.csv"' -e 'output1="doubleinout1_1.png"' \ -e 'input1="doubleinout1_1.csv"' doubleinout1.gp os.chdir('#')
Processing multiple scripts at once
Processing multiple scripts at once
In this example we generate two files named multiscript1_1.png and multiscript1_2.png containing graphs of numerical data from file multiscript1.csv. We process in single command two gnuplot scripts named multiscript1_1.gp and multiscript1_2.gp.
multiscript1_1.gp script:
# multiscript1_1.gp set terminal png; set output output1 plot input1 with lines;
multiscript1_2.gp script:
# multiscript1_2.gp set terminal png; set output output2 plot input1 with dots;
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph(['multiscript1_1.gp', 'multiscript1_2.gp'], gp_outputs= ['multiscript1_1.png', 'multiscript1_2.png'], gp_inputs = ['multiscript1.csv'] )
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'output2="multiscript1_2.png"' \ -e 'output1="multiscript1_1.png"' \ -e 'input1="multiscript1.csv"' \ multiscript1_1.gp multiscript1_2.gp os.chdir('#')
Controlling the names of command-line variables
Controlling the names of command-line variables
In this example we generate two files named namedinout1_1.png and namedinout1_2.png containing graphs of numerical data from files namedinout1_1.csv and namedinout1_2.csv respectively. The names of the input and output files are passed to namedinout1.gp script via command line variables. The names of these variables are controlled by defining gp_inputs and gp_outputs to be dictionaries.
namedinout1.gp script:
# namedinout1.gp set terminal png; set output first_out; plot first_in with lines; set output second_out; plot second_in with lines;
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph('namedinout1', gp_outputs= { 'first_out' : 'namedinout1_1.png', 'second_out': 'namedinout1_2.png'}, gp_inputs = { 'first_in' : 'namedinout1_1.csv', 'second_in' : 'namedinout1_2.csv' } )
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'first_in="namedinout1_1.csv"' \ -e 'second_out="namedinout1_2.png"' \ -e 'first_out="namedinout1_1.png"' \ -e 'second_in="namedinout1_2.csv"' namedinout1.gp os.chdir('#')
Using variant directories.
Using variant directories.
In this example we generate a file build/variant1.png containing a graph of numerical data from file src/variant1.csv. The directory named build is the variant build directory.
src/variant1.gp script:
# src/variant1.gp set terminal png; set output output1; plot input1 with lines;
src/SConscript file:
# src/SConscript Import(['env']) env.GplotGraph('variant1', gp_outputs = ['variant1.png'], gp_inputs = ['variant1.csv'])
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) VariantDir('build/', 'src/', duplicate = 0) SConscript('build/SConscript', exports = ['env'])
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#/build') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'output1="variant1.png"' \ -e 'input1="../src/variant1.csv"' ../src/variant1.gp os.chdir('#')
Changing working directory with chdir.
Changing working directory with chdir.
In this example we generate a file out/chdir1.png containing a graph of numerical data from file in/chdir1.csv. The gnuplot script is ./chdir1.gp and is stored in same directory as the SConstruct. All the job will be done in the out subdirectory.
chdir1.gp script:
# chdir1.gp set terminal png; set output output1; plot input1 with lines;
SConstruct file:
# SConstruct env = Environment(tools = ['gnuplot']) env.GplotGraph( 'chdir1.gp', gp_outputs = ['out/chdir1.png'], gp_inputs = ['in/chdir1.csv'], chdir='out')
Compiling the example yields (note, # is a placeholder for top level source directory)
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q os.chdir('#/out') /usr/bin/gnuplot -e 'output1="chdir1.png"' \ -e 'input1="../in/chdir1.csv"' ../chdir1.gp os.chdir('#')

variablelist.title: Construction variables used by gnuplot tool

listitem.para: Path to gnuplot executable.
The entire command line used to invoke gnuplot command.
A string displayed by scons when running gnuplot command.
Additional command-line options to gnuplot command.
Suffix of gnuplot script (source) files.
Base (prefix) of the placeholder for input file names. Used when the gp_inputs is not a dictionary.
Base (prefix) of the placeholder used as an output file name. Used when the gp_outputs is not a dictionary.
Base (prefix) of the placeholder for extra outputs. Used when the gp_extoutputs is not a dictionary.

section.title: Builder arguments
section.para: In addition to standard target and source arguments, the GplotBuilder has following arguments that may need some explanation.

listitem.para: Set current working directory for gnuplot command. By default, the working directory is changed to the directory of the SConscript file from which the builder is invoked. If you set chdir to string, it is interpreted as a path relative to the calling SConscript. Setting chdir to None/False or such, reverts to SCons default behavior.
Additional inputs used by gnuplot script(s). The gp_inputs may be a list or a dictionary.

In case of list, it should contain file names (or node objects) of files used by gnuplot script(s) as additional inputs. The order of the files in the list is important. The file names are passed to gnuplot via command-line options and are visible in the gnuplot script as variables named input1, input2, ..., etc.. If, for example, the list is defined as
['input_a.csv', 'input_b.csv']
the file names will be provided to gnuplot script(s) such as if the following variables were defined in gnuplot script(s)
input1 = "input_a.csv"; input2 = "input_b.csv";
The gnuplot script may then use the placeholders instead of file names, for example
plot input1 with lines, \ input2 with points;
The prefix 'input' may be changed to another one with
GPLOTINVAR.
Outputs generated by gnuplot script(s). The gp_outputs may be a list or a dictionary.

In case of list, it should contain file names (or node objects) of outputs generated by gnuplot script(s). The order of the files in the list is important. The file names are passed to gnuplot via command-line options and are visible in the gnuplot script as variables named output1, output2, ..., etc.. If, for example, the list is defined as
['output_a.png', 'output_b.png']
the file names will be provided to gnuplot script(s) such as if the following variables were defined in gnuplot script(s)
output1 = "output_a.png"; output2 = "output_b.png";
The gnuplot script may then use the placeholders instead of file names, for example
set output output1; # ... set output output2;
The prefix 'output' may be changed to another one with
GPLOTOUTVAR.
Extra output files generated by gnuplot script(s). The gp_extoutputs may be a list or a dictionary.

In case of list, it should contain file names (or node objects) of extra output files generated by gnuplot script(s). The order of the files in the list may be important. The file names are passed to gnuplot via command-line options and are visible in the gnuplot script as variables named eoutput1, eoutput2, ..., etc.. If, for example, the list is defined as
['eout_a.eps', 'eout_b.eps']
the file names will be provided to gnuplot script(s) such as if the following variables were defined in gnuplot script(s)
eoutput1 = "eout_a.csv"; eoutput2 = "eout_b.csv";
The prefix 'eoutput' may be changed to another one with
GPLOTEOUTVAR.
